episodes.title: The 2nd Biggest Reason People Are Trapped In Cults | I'm Trapped If I Leave, I'll Lose My Family!
episodes.description:
Who gets into this terrible situation, whereby they can say, I'm trapped, if I leave, I'll lose my family. Maybe you are in the Jehovah's Witnesses, Plymouth Brethren Christian Church, PBCC, Exclusive Brethren, Mormons, Church of Scientology, World Wide Church of God, Seventh Day Adventists or any cultic group that has rules that separate and destroy families.

Unfortunately many thousands of religious cult members across the world are in this predicament. I was, and I went through the awful wrestling in my mind for 4 years before I came to a place of peace and singlemindedness.

This video addresses the 2nd biggest reason that traps people in cults; The fear of losing their loved ones.

Here are the 2 further videos links on this subject that are mentioned:
1: How To Escape From A Religious Cult
https://youtu.be/5LW3vVCXvQw
2: Why Are cults So Difficult to Escape From?
https://youtu.be/Jn6nRIXp4gM

And here are the 3 scenarios mentioned in the video, why you might want to stay in the cult:

There are many reasons why people want to remain, even after discovering their group is cultic. For some, totally understandably, leaving and losing their family who might stay, is not an option. The goal of what I’m suggesting to you, is that you come to a place of peace and single-mindedness about where you are, at least for now, even if you find you have to take one day at a time.
I know what it is like to want to remain in a group, even though part of me wanted to leave. My struggle with making up my mind lasted four years. It took me that long to come to terms with the thought of possibly not seeing my family ever again.
Here’s a question to ask yourself. What comes first? Family, or freedom from the cult? Every situation and circumstance is different, so there is no one single answer for all. But if you were to remain in the cult option, there are 3 possible variations to consider:
A: Stay, and with your family aim to gradually sow seeds in discussion and research with them, that might eventually, with patience, make your family realise that it is a cult that you all, don’t want to be part of. I know someone who did just this. His wife and three children were committed to the cult, but after 18 months of research and really examining where they were, deeply looking into the issues of the self-righteousness, changing laws, hypocrisy, bigotry, control, fear, exclusivity etc, the whole family came to a place of agreement and they all happily left together.
A 2nd possibility: Stay with your family and have faith in God to guide you within the cult. Do you believe in a God that can guide you? If so, this is an option for you. If not, then it’s not an option.
The 3rd possibility: Stay with your family, put up and shut up. This is a real and realistic option that most take. There are certain things in life that we sometimes can’t cope with. Consider this; not all have the strength to leave a place that is all they have ever known. Leaving can be very daunting and can cause fear to even think about it. There was a time when for me, thinking of leaving my parents was traumatic and unthinkable. Is there a place for accepting this and seeing ourselves kindly? We all have strengths and weaknesses and by accepting this and not being hard on ourselves, we can still live our life knowing we are doing our best, with the strength we have at this time. Being ruthlessly honest with ourselves is always the best way forward and even if you live with a conflict of values and live your life under the control of the cult, at least you can live your life knowing you are doing your best, with the strength you have found in yourself so far. Give yourself a break. You can always change your mind in the future.
If after weighing up these options you choose to remain, at least for now, all respect to your decision and best wishes on the rest of your journey.
